data.text: ebikes are super fun. And they allow people with different physical ability levels to enjoy types of cycling they otherwise might not be able to.

data.text: and disabilities

data.text: Depending on distance/elevation, I plan to use my emtb or gravel bike.

data.text: I don't but as I'm getting older i was thinking i should try. I'm not a fan of ebikes at all but in fact they give a chance even to really old people to enjoy riding and that's great.
data.author: Zlatzky Tamas

data.text: - bear in mind good vigorous exercise like cycling helps keep you younger though. I know plenty of old guys in cycling club who can still race. Followed my mate up a long hill today. He was on an eBike [he has heart arrhythmia] and whilst I was working really hard, he said it was effortless.

data.text: its not totally undoable but you are extremely limited on where you can go and what you can do if you need to charge for 4 hours. Whats the range of your bike should be included if you want any real feedback
data.author: Dan Manning

data.text: katy trail in missouri is probably ebikeable. There are tons of credit card style stops where you would possibly be able to charge. You could probably bike that trail without a tent also if you wanted to go a little off trail in certain spots to lodge.
data.author: Dan Manning

data.text: some years ago there was an ebike competition of long distance biking from France to.. China I think it was. Its more common than some "snobs" may think. No reason to bash those users. Had a guest once, an older man off 55+ who ebiked (a modded bike, not for riding faster but longer) from France to Russia, then through Sweden going back home.

data.text: The Sun Trip... it's every year I think.

data.author: Gunnar Fehlau

data.text: I bought an e-bike with this in mind. I too late realized unpredictable range would be an issue. The promised 50 km is only if it is flat, warm and zero wind. Silly me thought I could pedal without assistance most of the way but the resistance of the magnets and the weight of the bike is a problem. So back to my hybrid I go. I will have to buy a second battery for that to work. BTW, I can easily do 100 km on a road bike, so the e-bike wasn‚Äôt because I cannot cycle without help. But because I might want to.
data.author: Louise Langlais

data.text: Where would you charge it?

data.text: Yes, Specialized Vado
data.author: Thomas Jackson

data.text: I have thought about this idea . You would probably need to build your own bike with range not speed as priority. With 2 batteries and staying in motels every night or campgrounds with electricity I would think one could realistically do 60-80 miles per day with available technology. I have a 415 watt hour mid drive e bike. On low assist ( which really isn‚Äôt that much help) I could get 35-40 miles over mixed terrain but the bike is 50 pounds with only 1 battery

data.text: What about from camp to camp, or nice small agritourism with fresh eggs and cheese on breakfast.
data.author: Marysia Bis

data.text: same same. Camping,B&B,Hotel from outlet to outlet, not self sufficient. I guess its possible but very limited. Probably will be some unpaved surfaces (Bike packing) but everyday. I see it as weekender or day trip. I know perfect place for that in norway - rallarvegen.
data.author: Validot Antan Ratk

data.text: I mean a lot of people do touring on ebikes, thats fun but foucus is not to be self sufficient and unpaved, so I would not call it Bikepacking oriented.
data.author: Validot Antan Ratk

data.text: So if I want to call myself "bickepacker" i must to be self sufficient? What about trying of food in restaurant or local market with fresh fishes? I think people want to categorize this sport too much. Germas for example have no a chanse to be a bickepaker in germany leggaly, because it is not allowed to pitch a tent in the wild in this country. For me, bikepackig means packing a bike in that way, so I can ride it everywhere. In the mountains, off the paths, crossing the river. if I find a nice place to camp I stay, if not I keep looking. Sometimes I sleep in agritourism because I want to try goat cheese. Nothing limits me.
data.author: Marysia Bis

data.text: basically yeah
data.author: Validot Antan Ratk

data.text:
"Our official definition from Bikepacking 101 Simply put, bikepacking is the synthesis of all-terrain cycling and self-supported backpacking. It evokes the freedom of multi-day backcountry hiking and travel off the beaten path, but with the range and thrill of riding a nimble bicycle. It‚Äôs about venturing further into places less traveled, both near and far, via singletrack trails, gravel, and forgotten dirt roads, carrying the essential gear, and not much more." https://bikepacking.com/plog/what-is-bikepacking/
What is Bikepacking? - BIKEPACKING.com
bikepacking.com

data.text: I tried e bike once and i loved it. It is a great option for group of people with different kind of sport condidtion. It a super way to ride together in the same speed, and everyone can ride in comfort. Anyway i would not choose e bike on rides in wild areas. E bike is super heavy, riding on it without electric support have no sense. For me of course. Anyway don't listen to people. Bikepacking is a riding with bags on it. And that's it. Sleeping in the wild is a bushcrafting.
data.author: Marysia Bis

data.text: In Germany lots of people use ebikes for touring. It is a great way for someone who has some fitness related issues, maybe just older, maybe has some disabilities. But only works in the more developed parts of the globe, and you probably have to stay in camp grounds or hotels. My wife had an ebike, and we were able to ride together despite her lungs (vascular system) disfunction. I regret only one thing, that we did not bought it earlier. She is gone now, and I only ride alone. So just do it!

data.author: Arthur Smith
Patrick Tse

data.text: Ran into 2 older ladies when I was out on the trail who were both on ebikes. Sure they could have been out there with no ebike capabilities, but without the assist they just flat out would not have been out there. They were basically credit card touring on gravel trails. Ride for the day, wine and dine, hotel to charge, then rinse and repeat. Made me excited for the future of biking especially when we get older and barriers to these activities get higher and higher. Live your life the way you want and forget about those who say otherwise.
data.author: Terrell Harrington

data.text: I owned a Haibike hard tail mb 2015 model the thing about those batteries at least mine was if you're almost dead and you can find a place to plug in all you had to do was plug that battery in for 1 hour and you would get 70-80 % of you battery back but it takes the extra 3-4 hours to get a full charge or that extra 20-30 %.
